questions.text: All of the following are non-pathological forms of amnesia, except:
questions.solution:
Explanation for Answer:

Dissociative amnesia is a pathological condition, defined as the inability to recall important personal information, usually of a traumatic or stressful nature, which is too extensive to be explained by ordinary forgetfulness.

It is classified under Dissociative Disorders in the DSM-5, not as a benign or non-pathological form of amnesia.

Diagnostic & Clinical Features:

  • Sudden onset, often after severe emotional trauma (e.g., abuse, combat, disasters).
  • Memory loss is usually retrograde and autobiographical.
  • Patients may appear perplexed, disoriented, or show confusion about identity.
  • The amnesia is reversible and not due to brain injury, substance use, or neurological illness.
  • Memory often returns spontaneously or gradually, sometimes triggered by cues or therapy.

Subtypes:

  • Localized amnesia: Cannot recall events from a specific time (e.g., post-trauma).
  • Selective amnesia: Can recall only parts of a time period.
  • Generalized amnesia: Complete memory loss of personal identity.
  • Systematized amnesia: Loss of memory related to a category (e.g., all memories of one person).
  • Continuous amnesia: Cannot remember events from a point up to the present.

Dissociative Fugue (Specifier in DSM-5):

  • Sudden, purposeful travel away from home with loss of personal identity.
  • The person may assume a new identity and appear normal to others.
  • Recovery may be abrupt, and the individual may not recall the fugue episode.

Diagnosis requires ruling out:

  • Neurological causes (e.g., seizures, dementia, head injury).
  • Substance-related amnesia (alcohol, sedatives, narcotics, etc.).
  • Malingering/factitious disorder.

Explanation of other options:

Childhood amnesia (Option A): Inability to recall events from early childhood, especially before age 3-4.

Hypnotic amnesia (Option C): A temporary, suggestion-induced inability to recall events during hypnosis.

Dream-associated amnesia (Option D): Common forgetfulness of dream content upon waking, not indicative of illness.

questions.text: A 45-year-old divorced male bus driver was referred for psychiatric consultation for complaints of memory loss for the previous 12 years, behaving and responding to the environment as if it were 12 years previously, e.g., he didn't recognize his 8-year-old son, and denied recollection of current events like the name of the current president. On mental status examination, the patient displayed intact intellectual function, and brain imaging was normal. The patient's mother described a family history of brutal beatings and physical discipline inflicted on the patient. Pick the correct diagnosis.
questions.solution:
Explanation for Answer:

The key features here are:

  • Sudden retrograde autobiographical memory loss
  • Normal cognition and imaging
  • History of childhood trauma
  • Absence of a medical or neurological cause

This pattern is classic for dissociative amnesia, a condition where individuals are unable to recall important personal information, often related to trauma, and the memory loss is inconsistent with normal forgetting.

Explanation of other options:

Post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) (Option B): While PTSD can feature dissociation and memory issues, it also requires symptoms like hypervigilance, nightmares, flashbacks, and re-experiencing of trauma, which are not present here.

Malingering (Option C): Involves intentional feigning of symptoms for external gain (e.g., legal, financial, avoidance). This patient shows no evidence of secondary gain and presents a credible trauma history.

choices.text: Rapid return of baseline cognitive function

questions.text: A 45-year-old divorced male bus driver was referred for psychiatric consultation for complaints of memory loss for the previous 12 years, behaving and responding to the environment as if it were 12 years previously, e.g., he didn't recognize his 8-year-old son, and denied recollection of current events like the name of the current president. On mental status examination, the patient displayed intact intellectual function, and brain imaging was normal. The patient's mother described a family history of brutal beatings and physical discipline inflicted on the patient. In the above case scenario, dissociative amnesia can be differentiated from Transient global amnesia by:
questions.solution:
Explanation for Answer:

Transient global amnesia can be mistaken for a dissociative amnesia, especially because stressful life events may precede either disorder. (Option A ruled out)

In transient global amnesia:

  • Sudden onset of complete anterograde amnesia and learning abilities
  • Pronounced retrograde amnesia
  • Preservation of memory for personal identity
  • Anxious awareness of memory loss with repeated, often perseverative, questioning
  • Overall normal behavior
  • Lack of gross neurological abnormalities in most cases
  • Rapid return of baseline cognitive function with a persistent short retrograde amnesia (Option C ruled out)
  • The patient is usually older than 50 years of age and shows risk factors for cerebrovascular disease. (Option D ruled out)

In dissociative amnesia, important autobiographical information and personal identity may also be lost.

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman reports episodes where she feels as though she is "living behind a glass" or "in a bubble", and experiences detachment from her thoughts, body, and feelings. The illustration below represents her described experience accurately. This phenomenon can be seen in all of the following conditions except:
questions.solution:
Explanation for Answer:

  • The symptoms described-feeling detached from one's body, thoughts, or surroundings-are classic for depersonalization/derealization experiences.
  • These experiences are most commonly associated with Depersonalization-Derealization Disorder, but they can also occur as features in several other psychiatric and neurological conditions.
  • Somatic Symptom Disorder is characterized by excessive focus on physical symptoms (e.g., pain, fatigue) and health anxiety. Depersonalization is not a core or typical symptom, making this the correct exception.

Conditions where depersonalization/derealization is commonly seen:

  • LSD abuse and other psychedelics (e.g., marijuana, mescaline) (Option A ruled out)
  • Panic disorder - frequently involves transient episodes of depersonalization during acute attacks (Option B ruled out)
  • Post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) - dissociation, including depersonalization, is a well-recognized symptom (Option C ruled out)
  • Also seen in: migraine, seizures, anticholinergic use, meditation, hypnosis, mirror gazing, sensory deprivation, and dissociative disorders.

questions.text: Under hypnosis or during psychotherapy, a patient may recover a memory of a painful experience or conflict-particularly of sexual or physical abuse-that is etiologically significant. This is known as:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Recovered Memory Syndrome refers to the return of previously repressed or inaccessible memories, usually of traumatic events, such as childhood sexual or physical abuse, often occurring during psychotherapy or hypnosis.
  • These memories were previously unavailable to conscious awareness, and when they emerge, they are often accompanied by intense emotional reliving (called abreaction).
  • The concept is clinically recognized, though controversial, due to the possibility of memory distortion or suggestion.

Explanation of the Other Options:

False memory syndrome (Option A): A variant of recovered memory syndrome. Occurs when the recalled memory did not happen, but the person firmly believes it is true and reacts accordingly. It can result from suggestions during therapy or hypnosis.

Narcoanalysis (Option C): A forensic or therapeutic technique involving the use of sedative drugs (like sodium amytal) to induce a twilight state where the person may reveal repressed thoughts or memories. It is not synonymous with recovered memory syndrome, although both aim to access unconscious material. Narcoanalysis is used more in investigative settings and is not a diagnostic category.

questions.text: Brainwashing is characterized by the idealization of captors under intense and prolonged coercion. As a result, victims manifest drastic alterations of their identity, values, and beliefs and undergo a regressive adaptation. Another term for this disorder is:
questions.solution:
Explanation for Answer:

According to DSM-5, identity disturbance due to prolonged and intense coercive persuasion is a dissociative process seen in extreme conditions like political imprisonment, cult indoctrination, or war captivity. Victims often:

  • Undergo pseudoidentity formation,
  • Show idealization of their captors, and
  • Exhibit regressive adaptation with loss of autonomy, emotional numbing, and trance-like states.

This dissociative state, with paralysis of will, frozen fright, and childlike dependency, is referred to as traumatic infantilism.

Explanation of Other Options:

Dissociative identity disorder (Option B): Involves two or more personality states due to chronic early trauma; not induced by external coercion.

Post-traumatic stress disorder (Option C): Involves hypervigilance and intrusive memories, but not identity restructuring or idealization of aggressors.

Adjustment disorder (Option D): A temporary and mild reaction to stress; does not include dissociation or identity changes.

questions.text: A person was found wandering on the streets after one month of running away from his home. His family members saw him and brought him for a psychiatric consultation. This kind of behavior can be seen in psychiatric patients in all of the following conditions, except:
questions.solution:
Explanation for Answer:

  • Panic attacks are sudden episodes of intense fear or discomfort accompanied by physical and psychological symptoms (e.g., palpitations, breathlessness, fear of dying).
  • During a panic attack, the person typically does not exhibit goal-directed motor activity like wandering or aimless travel. Instead, they often freeze or seek help.

Conditions where wandering is typically seen:

  • Dissociative Fugue: Sudden, purposeful travel away from home. Inability to recall past identity. May establish a new identity (Option A ruled out)
  • Schizophrenia: Disorganized or catatonic type. Wandering due to hallucinations or delusions (Option C ruled out)
  • Mania (Bipolar Disorder): Increased energy and impulsivity. May wander due to grandiose ideas or impulsive decisions (Option D ruled out)
  • Delirium: Acute confusional state. Disorientation with purposeless wandering
  • Dementia (e.g., Alzheimer's disease): Common, especially in middle to late stages. Wandering may be aimless or purposeful (e.g., "going home" behavior)
  • Intellectual Disability / Autism Spectrum Disorder: Wandering (also called elopement) may occur without awareness of danger. Especially in younger individuals
  • Substance Intoxication or Withdrawal: E.g., alcohol, hallucinogens, stimulants. Disorganized thinking and impaired judgment may lead to wandering
  • Severe Depression (with psychotic features): Rare, but can involve purposeless or suicidal wandering

questions.text: Psychotherapeutic technique proven to be effective in dissociative identity disorder?
questions.solution:
Explanation for Answer:

Dissociative Identity Disorder (DID) is marked by the presence of two or more distinct identity states with amnesia for daily events and personal information.

Among the psychotherapeutic options, hypnosis has been found especially useful for:

  • Accessing alter personalities and their sequestered memories.
  • Allowing patients to revisit traumatic experiences in a safe and controlled mental state.
  • Facilitating integration of dissociated identity fragments.

According to DSM-5 descriptions, DID often develops in response to overwhelming trauma, particularly early in life, and hypnotic states may help uncover these repressed events and bring them into conscious awareness without overwhelming the patient.

Explanation of Other Options:

Dialectical Behavior Therapy (DBT) (Option B): Most effective for borderline personality disorder and emotion dysregulation, not for accessing or integrating dissociated identities.

Mindfulness-Based Therapy (Option C): Useful in stress and anxiety management; may offer general benefit in emotional regulation, but not a core intervention for DID.

Group Therapy (Option D): Generally not preferred in DID due to the complex nature of identity switching, confidentiality concerns, and potential for overstimulation or retraumatization.

questions.text: A 21-year-old lady presented with a history of episodes where she would behave as if possessed by some spirit. She would display extraordinary strength and become aggressive towards her family members, speak in a foreign language, and display bizarre behavior. She would always claim amnesia for the event. Pick the most suitable diagnosis for her condition.
questions.solution:
Explanation for Answer:

Possession trance is a subtype of dissociative trance disorder characterized by:

  • Marked alteration in consciousness with the replacement of personal identity by a new identity, often attributed to a spirit, deity, or supernatural force.
  • The person may speak in a foreign language, show extraordinary strength, or display stereotypical culturally shaped behaviors.
  • There is typically partial or complete amnesia for the event.
  • It is only considered a disorder if:
    • It is not a culturally accepted practice (e.g., not part of a ritual).
    • It causes significant distress or functional impairment.
    • It does not occur exclusively during a psychotic disorder, substance use, or a general medical condition.

Explanation of other options:

Dissociative trance (Option A): Involves an altered state of consciousness or loss of personal identity, but without the replacement by a possessing identity.

Dissociative identity disorder (DID) (Option C): Involves multiple personality states, typically stemming from early trauma, but the identities are not perceived as external forces like spirits.

Dissociative amnesia (Option D): Involves amnesia for personal information, but does not involve trance states or replacement of identity.
